statement.p: Suppose that as dry air rose its temperature dropped in a linear fashion. The temperature was measured at 1200 ft MSL as \displaystyle{23}^{\circ} C and at 3200 ft MSL as \displaystyle{26.8}^{\circ} C.
What is the rate of change of temperature with respect to altitude? Preview Question 1 Part 1 of 2 Â
Your response may be as a fraction such as 2/1000 or decimal such as 0.002
What does this data imply about the temperature at 0 ft MSL?

solution.p: We want the ratio of temperature drop to altitude increase. \displaystyle\frac{{{26.8}-{23}}}{{{3200}-{1200}}}=-{0.0019}

Now that we know that ratio we can use a linear model to find the temperature at sea level. Because the temperature increases (we are going down not up) at a rate of -1.9 per 1000 ft the temperature will be expected to increase \displaystyle{1200}{\left(-\frac{{1.9}}{{1000}}\right)}=-{2.28}. That will result in a temperature of \displaystyle{23}\pm{2.28}={20.72}.
